title-group.article-title: A novel NXT control method for implementing force sensing and recycling in a training robot

article-meta.aff: Department and Graduate School of Computer Science, National Pingtung University of Education, Taiwan, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Chen-Yuan Chen, Department and Graduate School of Computer Science, National Pingtung University of Education, No. 4–18, Ming Shen Road, Pingtung 90003, Taiwan, People’s Republic of China Email: cyc@mail.npue.edu.tw

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The rise of environmental awareness has led to finding ways for increasing the resource returns-ratio for households and public places. The purpose of the current study is the development of an NXT intelligent recycling barrel by using the flow method of artificial intelligence discrimination for tree classification. How to utilize LEGO NXT to carry out waste sorting and specifically contributes two main purposes: increasing the recycling rate and promoting the sustainable use of resources as well as reducing the manpower recycling cost and promoting automation of recycling operations in the future are first studied. The system was implemented by the LEGO NXT intelligent brick with a sound controller to discriminate between metal and non-metal. Meanwhile, the NXT weight identification is used to sort iron cans and aluminum ones, and the NXT shape identification is used to sort polyester bottles from paper. The classification rate of the current system has reached 77%.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: To reach the aim of sustainable development, recycling and decreasing the amount of trash are the active methods. Processing for recycling and reuse means that over 40% of the trash can be retrieved by available resources. Trash such as polyester (PET) bottles, cans, plastic, Tetra Paks, glass and paper must be sorted first, then disposed of to reduce the harm to the environment from harmful materials such as scrap tires or mercury batteries.

There are many advantages to recycling. Recycling and remaking scrap paper can not only save 75% of the energy and 50% of the water used to make new paper, but can also reduce air pollution by 75–79%. Recycling a ton of scrap paper is equal to saving 20 trees. The process of recycling aluminum cans takes 19 times less than making new aluminum cans from bauxite. The recycling and remaking of polyvinylchloride (PVC) plastics can reduce the production of dioxins from burning them. Kitchen waste can become organic fertilizer to reduce damage to our environment caused by chemical fertilizers. In addition, the reduction in the quantity and moisture content of the refuse means that the temperature within the incinerator will be increased. Therefore, air pollution will be reduced.

The Environmental Protection Administration is seeking to implement the “Complete Garbage Sorting and Zero Waste Project”. The “NXT intelligent recycling barrel” was created to establish an automated domestic recycling system to reach the aim of sustainable utilization of natural resources. The purpose of the current study is the development of a NXT intelligent recycling barrel by using the flow method of artificial intelligence discrimination for tree classification including:
increasing the rate of domestic natural resource recycling to reduce the quantity of refuse, and promote sustainable use of natural resources.
decreasing labor recycling costs, and comprehensively automating the task of natural resource recycling.

sec.title: 2. Manufacturing and effectiveness analysis of the NXT intelligent recycling barrel
2.1. Usage of the LEGO NXT intelligent brick
2.1.1. NXT intelligent brick
sec.p:
The NXT Intelligent brick is the brain of the robot with a 32-byte processor containing four inputs, three outputs and a USB port. The output controls a motor. The input receives messages from four sensors; see Figure 1. Figure 1.
LEGO NXT Intelligent brick.

sec.title: 2.1.2. Sensor
sec.p:
This study employs three ultrasonic sensors (US) (Figure 2(a)) and one sound sensor (Figure 2(b)). The purpose of the ultrasonic sensor is to detect the distance between an object and a sensor. Its detection range is from 0 to 255 (inch/cm). A sound sensor detects the volume in the range is from 0 to 100 (inch/cm). The volume is divided into two kinds, one is decibel (dB), and the other is decibel adjusted (dBA). dB is the detecting range for a machine. It can detect a certain sound which is slighter less than detectable by human hearing. It is too sensitive to be easily disturbed by the external world. Figure 2.
(a) Ultrasonic sensor; (b) Sound sensor.
Figure 3.
Appearance and internal structure of servo motor.

sec.title: 2.1.3. servomotor
sec.p: An angle sensor can detect speed and distance. When the robot is moving, its speed can be adjusted. Its precision can be controlled accurately to within 1 degree.

sec.title: 2.2. Sorting process for the intelligent recycling barrel
sec.p: The purpose of the wisdom recycling barrel is mainly to sort out tin cans, aluminum cans, plastic bottles and paper.

First, tin cans, aluminum cans, cartons, Tetra Paks and plastic bottles are divided into two kinds. One is metal (tin cans and aluminum cans), and the other is non-metal (cartons, Tetra Paks and plastic bottles). In the metal category, the weight of a tin can is heavier than an aluminum can. They can therefore be distinguished according to weights by the intelligent recycling barrel. Non-metal objects are distinguished by their shape, as presented in Figure 4. Figure 4.
Flow chart of the sorting process for the intelligent resource recovery barrel.
a. Tin cans, aluminum cans, cartons, Tetra Paks, round cartons, PET bottles, b. Metals (tin and aluminum cans), c. Cartons, Tetra Paks, round cartons, d. Nonmetals (cartons, Tetra Paks, round cartons, PET bottles), e. Tin cans, f. Aluminum cans, g. PET bottles, h. Cartons, i. Paper, j. Sound sensor determination, k. Two ultrasonic sensors for calculating deviation, l. Tin/Aluminum sorting device, m. Ultrasonic sensor detects no object, n. Ultrasonic sensor detects an object.

PS. US2, US3 refer to Figure 5 (structural design drawing). Figure 5.
Structural design of the system.
Figure 6.
Side view of the system.

sec.title: 2.2.1. Manufacture principle
sec.p: First, a sound sensor detects metal or non-metal items according the volume intensity caused by an aluminum ruler hitting the objects. The sound of metal things colliding with the aluminum ruler is louder and clearer than that for non-metal things. Hence, metal things can be distinguished from non-metal ones by the volume intensity. An ultrasonic sensor must be employed to assist in increasing the accuracy of the sound sensor. An object must drop within a certain limited area, since the volume detected will be valid.

If the volume reaches a certain level so the object is determined to be metal, servo meter A will turn 20 degrees to make the tin can roll to the tin-aluminum sorting section, as in Figure 7. Figure 7.
Sorting process for metal cans.

The tin-aluminum can sorting device utilizes inertia and gravity to operate a balance plate between points A and B. When a heavy item is added to point B it makes point A become lighter. Moreover, a pivot is located near point B to increase the torque of point A, as in Figure 8. Figure 8.
Structural drawing of tin-aluminum cans’ sorting device.

During the process of rolling across the balance plate in the tin-aluminum can sorting device, since the weight of the aluminum can is lighter, when it rolls through point A, the torque is insufficient to lift a heavy object on point B. The inertial movement will cause the can to fall into the aluminum can collector, as in Figure 9. Figure 9.
Process of aluminum cans’ sorting.

On the contrary, since a tin can is heavier, when rolling through point A, the torque will be bigger than point B’s. It will fall into the tin can collector, as in Figure 10. Figure 10.
Process of tin cans’ sorting.

If the volume does not reach a certain level and the object is determined to be non-metal, it will remain on balance plate A for a second test as in Figure 11. Figure 11.
Non-metal sorting.

The classification of cartons (included Tetra Paks) and polyester (PET) bottles includes three kinds. The placement method is made according to the objects’ shape. Cartons have two kinds of shapes. One is square and the other is round. Since the edges of square cartons are right, and their surfaces are flat, when they drop to the balance plate from the slope, the relative resistance they accept is high. Hence, they will drop into a fixed place (marked in red). An ultrasonic sensor will detect their distance and then determine whether they are square cartons (or Tetra Paks); see Figure 12. Figure 12.
Square cartons dropping into a fixed place.

Since the resistance accepted by round cartons is low, they will not drop into the fixed place for square cartons (marked in red). However, PET bottles will drop into into the same place as round cartoons which will cause an erroneous judgment; see Figure 13. Figure 13.
Situations of objects dropping into the same place.

Hence, this device assembly must include two ultrasonic sensors, as in Figure 14. Figure 14.
Two ultrasonic sensors are added (outlined in red) frame to discriminate. between cartons and polyester (PET) bottles.

If a deviation is detected from bottle mouth to bottle body that is bigger than a certain value, it can be determined to be a PET bottle; see Figure 15. Figure 15.
Deviation detected from bottle mouth to bottle body by two ultrasonic sensors.

If the deviation detected from bottle mouth to bottle body is smaller than a certain value, it is determined to be a round cartoon; see Figure 16. Figure 16.
Bottom deviation of a round cartoon is smaller.

After discriminating between a carton or a PET bottle, servo meter A turns 90 degrees to make an object drop onto balance plate B, as in Figure 17. Figure 17.
Action after discriminating between a cartoon and a polyester (PET) bottle.

If an object is a PET bottle, servo meter B will turn 20 degrees to make it drop into a PET bottle collector, as in Figure 18. Figure 18.
Movement of a polyester (PET) bottle.

If an object is a carton, servo meter will 90 degrees to make it drop into a carton collector to finish the sorting of cartons and PET bottles, as in Figure 19. Hence, the classification of tin cans, aluminum cans, PET bottles and cartons will be completed. Figure 19.
Movement of cartoons.

sec.title: 2.3. Program code (Usage of NXC)
sec.p: The pseudo of the algorithm developed in the system is as follows:
if(SensorUS(IN_1) <= 23) // an object drops into a certain place
if(Sensor(IN_2) > 10 ) // a sound should be high (over 10) to avoid being overly sensitive
if(Sensor(IN_2) < 75 ) // if a sound is lower than 35, object is non-metal.
else if(Sensor(IN_2) >= 75)// if a sound is higher than 75, object is metal.
else // a sound is lower than 10
else // there is nothing detected in a certain place

sec.title: 2.4. Efficiency
sec.p: Trash recognized by this recycling system: tin cans, aluminum cans, cartons, Tetra Pak, round cartons and PET bottles. They are divided into four kinds: “tin can”, “aluminum can”, “paper” and “PET bottles”. Paper includes cartons, Tetra Paks, and round cartons.

First, many different kinds of objects were collected as experimental samples. Tin cans are shown in Table 1. Aluminum cans are shown in Table 2. Paper is shown in Table 3. PET bottles are shown in Table 4. Then, trash is thrown into the recycling bin by the appropriate operations. Table 1.
Tin cans commonly seen in supermarket
Tin can A Tin can B Tin can C
Figure 2–6(a) 350−ml Tin can Figure 2–6(b) 250−ml Tin can Figure 2–6(c) Common tin can
Table 2.
Aluminum cans commonly seen in the present market
Aluminum can A Aluminum can B
Figure 2–6(d) 350−ml Aluminum can Figure 2–6(e) 250−ml Aluminum can
Table 3.
Cartons commonly seen in the present market
Carton Tetra Pak Round carton
Figure 2–6(k) 450−ml carton Figure 2–6(l) 350−ml Tetra Pak Figure 2–6(m) 600−ml round carton
All samples were sorted correctly. Each sample was tested 50 times. The results are presented in Table 5.
Table 4.
PET bottles commonly seen in the present market
PET bottle A PET bottle B PET bottle C
Figure 2–6(f) 600ml round PET bottle Figure 2–6(g) 330ml hexagonal PET bottle Figure 2–6(h) 900ml hexagonal PET bottle
PET bottle D PET bottle E
Figure 2–6(i) 400−ml curved PET bottle Figure 2–6(j) 600−ml Hexagonal PET bottle
PET: polyester.

All samples were sorted correctly. Each sample was tested 50 times. The results are presented in Table 5. Table 5.
Results and analysis of sensitivity
Sort Test sample Test times Successful sorting times Success ratio Sensitivity
Tin cans Tin can A 50 50 100% Good
Tin can B 50 40 80% Good
Tin can C 50 25 50% Bad
Aluminum cans Aluminum can A 0 50 100% Good
Aluminum can B 50 44 88% Good
paper Cartoon 50 47 94% Good
Tetra Pak 50 48 96% Good
round cartoon 50 50 100% Good
PET bottles PET bottle A 50 43 86% Good
PET bottle B 50 29 58% Bad
PET bottle C 50 20 40% Bad
PET bottle D 50 50 100% Good
PET bottle E 50 41 82% Good

After analyzing the result, since the shape of tin can C is flat and small it can fall into the dead space for a sensor, so its successful sorting ratio was low. Furthermore, because of the smaller shape of aluminum can B, it was easily displaced which caused sorting failure.

Sorting was most successful for paper. Only few cartoons and Tetra Paks did not drop into the correct place. The failure ratio was 4–6%. Since the volume of PET bottle B is smaller, it was easily displaced. The square PET bottle C was too asymmetrical which caused it to be displaced.

The conclusions of the test results are as follows:
Except for paper, the degree of accuracy is better with round shaped objects; expect for round shaped samples, others might be displaced due to asymmetrical forces and could easily fall into a dead space for a sensor which would cause sorting failure.
If a sensor is placed at the midpoint or smaller volume samples are not at the specified place detected by the sensor, they will not be detected.
A success ratio of lower than 80% is categorized as bad sensitivity. Among the 13 drinking vessels seen commonly in the present market, ten have a better sensitivity. The overall sorting success ratio is 77%.

sec.title: 3.1. Structure and questions for the NXT intelligent recycling barrel
1. Limits of the structure design
sec.p: Since the line connecting the LEGO NXT sensors, servo meters and a host has a limited length, and a host connects four sensors at most, the structural design must have some restriction.

sec.title: 2. The mouth of PET bottles must follow the direction of throwing
sec.p:
Sensors should be placed as shown in Figure 20 to detect the deviation between the mouth and the body. Figure 20.
Vertical view of the structure and direction of movement.
Figure 21.
Trash size is bigger than the hole.

sec.title: 3. The shape of the tin and aluminum cans should be intact
sec.p: While being thrown, trash rolls down a slope to reduce the force of descent. If the shapes of the tin and aluminum cans are not round, their force caused by colliding with an aluminum ruler might be too strong for them to be judged as non-metals by the sound sensor.

sec.title: 4. Limitations of trash size
sec.p:
Like Figure 21, trash size is limited to under 30 cm. Trash over 30 cm cannot be thrown into the device because of the structural design. If oversize trash is forced into the hole, it might cause a misjudgment by the sensor. If trash smaller than 10 cm is thrown in, it might cause the situation shown in Figure 22. Figure 22.
The place of an object cannot be detected by the ultrasonic sensor.

sec.title: 1. Improvement of the PET bottle mouth following a certain direction
sec.p:
Add a NXT host and two ultrasonic sensors in the position shown in Figure 23 to detect deviation between the PET bottle mouth and its body. Figure 23.
Addition of ultrasonic sensors to solve the direction limitations of the bottle mouth.

sec.title: 2. Improvement of trash size
sec.p:
Enlarge the hole and increase the slope, and add an ultrasonic sensor at each US1 to reduce the dead space, as in Figure 24. Figure 24.
Addition of ultrasonic sensors to detect the dead space.

sec.title: 4. Conclusion
sec.p: Heuristic innovations are springing up (Abbas and Othman, 2012; Abd-Alla et al., 2011; Chang, 2012; Chen CW, 2004, 2006a, 2006b, 2007a, 2007b, 2007c, 2008, 2009a, 2009b, 2009c, 2009d, 2010a, 2010b, 2010c, 2010d, 2010e, 2011a, 2011b, 2011c, 2011d, 2011e, 2011f, 2011g, 2011h, 2012a, 2012b, 2012c, 2012d, 2012e, 2012f, 2012g; Chen CW et al., 2012a, 2012b, 2012c, 2012d; Chen CY, 2005a, 2005b, 2006a, 2006b, 2007a, 2007b, 2007c, 2007d, 2007e, 2007f, 2007g, 2008a, 2008b, 2009a, 2009b, 2010a, 2010b, 2010c, 2010d, 2010e, 2010f, 2010g, 2011a, 2011b, 2011c, 2011d, 2012a, 2012b, 2012c, 2012d, 2012e, 2012f, 2012g, 2012h, 2012i; Chen CY et al., 2012a, 2012b, 2012c, 2012d, 2012e, 2012f; Chen PC et al., 2008, 2009a, 2009b, 2011a, 2011b; Chen SF, 2012; Chen TH, 2008, 2009, 2010; Chiementin et al., 2012; Cheng et al., 2011; Chiang et al., 2010; Chiang and Wang, 2011; Chiou et al., 2011; Chu et al., 2011; Cigada et al., 2012; Hsiao et al., 2005a, 2005b, 2005c, 2005d, 2005e; Hsieh et al., 2006; Hsu et al., 2011, 2012a, 2012b; Huang et al., 2012; Jayaswal et al., 2011; Kuo, 2010, 2011a, 2011b; Kuo and Chen, 2012a, 2012b; Lee SC, 2011a, 2011b; Lee WI, 2010a, 2010b, 2010c, 2010d, 2011, 2012a, 2012b, 2012c; Li et al., 2012; Lin CL et al., 2009; Lin JW, 2011, 2012a, 2012b; Lin ML, 2009, 2010, 2011, 2012; Liu KC, 2010; Liu KC et al., 2012; Liu KFR, 2009, 2011, 2012; Liu TY et al., 2011, 2012; Macha et al., 2012; Mahmoud, 2012; Manna, 2012; Shen et al., 2011; Shih CH et al., 2010, 2011, 2012; Shih BY et al., 2010a, 2010b, 2011a, 2011b, 2011c, 2011d, 2012a, 2012b, 2012c, 2012d, 2012e; Soundarrajan and Sumathi, 2011, 2012; Su et al., 2011; Tang et al., 2011; Tsai et al., 2008; Tsai and Chen, 2010, 2011a, 2011b; Tseng et al., 2012a, 2012b, 2012c, 2012d, Yang et al., 2008a, 2008b; Yang and Chen, 2012; Yeh et al., 2008, 2010, 2012; Yu et al., 2011a, 2011b; Zhang et al., 2010a, 2010b, 2011a, 2011b, 2011c, 2011d; Zhao 2010a, 2010b, 2011a, 2011b; Zheng et al., 2011; Zhu et al., 2011). This study utilizes LEGO NXT to create an automatic trash sorting system. The purpose is not only to improve human living quality but also to develop a new NXT application for daily life.

The structure of the NXT intelligent recycling barrel is required to be simple to obtain the most benefit. Since quantities of sensors and servo meters are limited to equip an NXT host, it might cause a dead space for failure to recognize an object.

Besides, the resistance of the servo meters is higher, which impedes the functioning of the NXT intelligent recycling barrel. This will be improved for application in human life in future. The conclusions of this paper are as follows:

sec.title: 1. Improvement of the structure
sec.p: The volume of the NXT intelligent recycling barrel is currently too large to collect more trash. Additionally, the dead spaces caused by the sensors and the resistance of the servo meters lead to device failure. The abovementioned problems need to be improved to make NXT intelligent recycling barrel more practical.

sec.title: 4.1. Implications
sec.p: If the NXT intelligent recycling barrel develops well, it can be applied in houses, schools and public places to enhance the recycling ratio and save on manpower recycling costs.

sec.title: 4.2. Future expectations
sec.p: The function of recognizing general waste will be added to the NXT intelligent recycling barrel in future. Moreover, it can recognize and sort all trash being thrown in in the meantime. When the trash sorting collector overfills, it also can present this situation. In a word, the NXT intelligent recycling barrel will be completely automatic.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: The authors are grateful for the support of their funding body. They are also most grateful for the kind assistance of Professor Ali Nayfeh, Editor of JVC, and for the constructive suggestions from the anonymous reviewers, all of which has led to the making of several corrections and have greatly aided us to improve the presentation of this paper.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the National Science Council of the Republic of China (grant numbers NSC 99-2628-E-153-001 and NSC 100-2628-E-153-001).
